abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, the project outcome is
            unsatisfactory, though sustainability is likely, and the
            institutional development impact is modest. Several lessons
            drawn form the project suggest the following. Given the
            complexity of this type of umbrella project, it is strongly
            recommended that in the future, such projects utilize the
            new Bank lending mechanisms, such as the Adaptable Program
            Loan, namely utilizing a phased programmatic lending
            process, i.e., first, funding comprehensive feasibility
            analysis, and project design; secondly, funding project
            construction; and, third, funding agricultural development,
            and technical assistance (TA). However, project-finance
            planning should carefully evaluate the Government's
            ability to meet counterpart funding requirements, and,
            macroeconomic factors must be taken into consideration
            during preparation. Moreover, the strong tendency among all
            borrowers to emphasize the construction of infrastructure,
            and to divert project funding from later phases, such as TA,
            and agricultural development to meet overruns in the cost of
            infrastructure, could and should be avoided by the
            programmatic lending instrument, which separates the project
            phases, avoiding intermingling funds. Further lessons
            include the importance of clear, and reliable project
            design; of realistic supervision cost estimates, as well as
            time schedules to avoid implementation delays; of effective
            monitoring criteria, and identified performance indicators;
            and, of institutional strengthening of the implementing agencies.
